Line 28: Line 28:
The University of Louisville Health Sciences Center participated in the development of a highly [[HPV vaccine|effective vaccine]] against cervical cancer in 2006,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://januvia.blogspot.com/2006/12/merck-markets-cancer-vaccine.html|title=Merck, Januvia and Blood Pressure Medicine: Merck Markets Cancer Vaccine Discovered by Louisville Doctors}}</ref> the first fully self-contained [[artificial heart]] transplant surgery,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heartpioneers.org/patient/gallery/conference1.html|title=Robert L. Tools|accessdate=2006-06-08}}</ref> the first successful [[hand transplantation]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/411618|title=America's First Successful Hand Transplant -- One Year Later|date=2000-01-31|accessdate=2009-03-31|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5fggJ8G6j|archivedate=2009-03-31}}</ref> and the development of the [[Pap smear]] test{{Fact|Papanicolaou was never at Louisville|date=April 2009}}. U of L is also credited with the first civilian [[ambulance]], the nation's first accident services, now known as an [[emergency department|emergency room]] (ER), and one of the first [[blood bank]]s in the US.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://louisville.edu/ur/ucomm/mags/summer2000/cover_story.html|title=U of L Magazine - Summer 2000}}</ref>
The University of Louisville Health Sciences Center participated in the development of a highly [[HPV vaccine|effective vaccine]] against cervical cancer in 2006,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://januvia.blogspot.com/2006/12/merck-markets-cancer-vaccine.html|title=Merck, Januvia and Blood Pressure Medicine: Merck Markets Cancer Vaccine Discovered by Louisville Doctors}}</ref> the first fully self-contained [[artificial heart]] transplant surgery,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heartpioneers.org/patient/gallery/conference1.html|title=Robert L. Tools|accessdate=2006-06-08}}</ref> the first successful [[hand transplantation]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/411618|title=America's First Successful Hand Transplant -- One Year Later|date=2000-01-31|accessdate=2009-03-31|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5fggJ8G6j|archivedate=2009-03-31}}</ref> and the development of the [[Pap smear]] test{{Fact|Papanicolaou was never at Louisville|date=April 2009}}. U of L is also credited with the first civilian [[ambulance]], the nation's first accident services, now known as an [[emergency department|emergency room]] (ER), and one of the first [[blood bank]]s in the US.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://louisville.edu/ur/ucomm/mags/summer2000/cover_story.html|title=U of L Magazine - Summer 2000}}</ref>
â
[[Image:Louisville Cardinals Alternate Logo.svg|left|85px|]]
 
Since 1999, U of L has made the largest gains of any university in [[National Institutes of Health]] research ranking, with its NIH funding increasing 277 percent and its rank increasing 30 places.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uoflhealthcare.com/ulhc/news_thumbnail/VSEL%20_for_More_Information.pdf|title=VSEL for More Information|accessdate=2006-06-08|format=PDF}}</ref> As of 2006 among public [[Higher education in the United States|U.S. universities]], the [[melanoma]] clinic ranks third, the [[neurology]] research program fourth, and the [[spinal cord]] research program 10th in NIH funding.
Since 1999, U of L has made the largest gains of any university in [[National Institutes of Health]] research ranking, with its NIH funding increasing 277 percent and its rank increasing 30 places.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uoflhealthcare.com/ulhc/news_thumbnail/VSEL%20_for_More_Information.pdf|title=VSEL for More Information|accessdate=2006-06-08|format=PDF}}</ref> As of 2006 among public [[Higher education in the United States|U.S. universities]], the [[melanoma]] clinic ranks third, the [[neurology]] research program fourth, and the [[spinal cord]] research program 10th in NIH funding.
